subject: statistics
title: Type I and Type II Errors
contentHtml:
Type I errors occur when a true null hypothesis is rejected, while Type II errors happen when a false alternative hypothesis is accepted.

The significance level α represents the maximum probability of Type I error. A lower α means fewer Type I errors but also lower power to detect true effects.
problemHtml: Suppose we're testing a new medicine's effectiveness. We set α = 0.05 and the test statistic yields a p-value of 0.03.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Compare the p-value to α", "mathHtml": "\(p-value < \alpha\)", "explanation": "If the p-value is below our chosen significance level, we reject the null hypothesis"} ],
intuition: Understanding Type I and II errors helps you make informed decisions in statistical testing.

In statistical hypothesis testing, two types of errors can occur: Type I error and Type II error.

A Type I error occurs when a true null hypothesis is rejected, while a Type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis is not rejected.

subject: statistics
title: Type I and Type II Errors
contentHtml:
In statistical hypothesis testing, two types of errors are crucial to understand: Type I and Type II.

  • A Type I error occurs when a true null hypothesis is rejected, resulting in a false positive. The probability of this occurring is controlled by the significance level α.
  • A Type II error occurs when a false alternative hypothesis is accepted, resulting in a false negative. The power of a test is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it's actually false.
